Expectation1: Provide guidance and wisdom based on life experience
Situation1: A grandchild brings up a general question about navigating a new phase of their life.
Expectation2: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation2: A I04iend sends a text message complaining about having a long, boring day.
Story: I was sitting at the kitchen table, sipping tea, when my granddaughter, Emma, plopped down across from me. She looked anxious, twirling a strand of hair around her finger. “Grandma, how did you know what to do after high school? I feel so lost.” I could see she wanted guidance, maybe even a story from my own life to help her make sense of her choices. I opened my mouth to answer, but my phone buzzed. It was my friend, Linda: “Rough day. Everything feels pointless. Can you talk?” I knew Linda needed me to listen, to be present and supportive, not to offer solutions but to simply hear her out. Emma’s eyes were on me, searching for wisdom, while my phone screen glowed with Linda’s plea for comfort. My heart tugged in two directions—one toward the role of wise grandmother, the other toward the role of empathetic friend. I felt the weight of both expectations pressing in, unsure which need to answer first.
